title: 109_s1375
content: The Act titled "Indian Arts and Crafts Amendments Act of 2005" amends Section 5 of the Act related to criminal proceedings and civil actions for misrepresentations in Indian arts and crafts. The term 'Federal law enforcement officer' includes officers defined in section 115(c) of title 18, United States Code, and officers with authority under the Indian Law Enforcement Reform Act for violations outside Indian country. The Board can refer complaints of violations to any Federal law enforcement officer for investigation. The Board can refer complaints of violations to Federal law enforcement officers for appropriate investigation. Findings of an investigation must be submitted to the Attorney General and the Board. The Board may recommend criminal proceedings to the Attorney General and provide support as needed. Additionally, the Board may suggest civil actions to the Attorney General as an alternative or in addition to criminal proceedings. The Attorney General can initiate a civil action under section 6 of the Act for misrepresentation. Amendments include defining "Indian" and "Indian product" in the Act. The term 'Indian tribe' is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, including formally recognized Indian groups. The 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of the Interior. In subsection (b), subsection (c) is changed to subsection (d). Subsection (c) now refers to subsection (b) and replaces "suit" with "the civil action." Subsection (d) states that a civil action under subsection (b) can be initiated by the Attorney General at the request of the Secretary on behalf of an Indian tribe or an Indian. In civil actions under this section, amounts recovered are paid to the Indian tribe, Indian, or Indian arts and crafts organization on whose behalf the action was initiated. In civil actions under this section, the Attorney General may deduct the cost of the civil action and attorney's fees from the recovered amount. In civil actions under this section, the Attorney General may deduct the cost of the civil action and attorney's fees from the recovered amount. The investigation awarded under subsection (c) reimburses the Board for activities related to the civil action, with provisions for Indian tribes to deduct costs and attorney's fees. Additionally, a savings provision is included in subsection (e) for certain circumstances. The definition of 'Indian tribe' is amended to include formally recognized Indian groups by State legislative or similar organizations with tribal recognition authority. The Senate passed the legislation on July 28, 2005, as attested by Emily J. Reynolds, Secretary.
